text: Oh 'banahna hi everyone Anthony Fantana
here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new
temples album Sun structures this is the
debut full-length LP from uk-based rock
outfit temples I've had a lot of people
suggesting this record to me usually
tagging it with something like whoa hey
dude if you like Tim and Paula then give
this record a listen because they're
both psychedelic pop and you're gonna
like that but the thing is while I do
like a lot of tame Impala's songs and I
did love their last record there's
always been something about their
unapologetic in-your-face nostalgia that
has always sort of rubbed me the wrong
way on their second full-length LP I
feel like the van really upped the
quality of the songwriting and the
melody writing and the production too
and it was so good that the blatant 60
psych pop worship wasn't so distracting
however in the case of temples at least
for me it is incredibly distracting even
if the Basie kick drums and the watery
guitars and the lavish keys are all
executed and mixed really well and just
sound gorgeous my biggest issue with the
instrumentation on this record lies in
the vocals I feel like they give in too
easily to the temptation to play the
revolver card and they deliver very
little in terms of personality as a
result if this album were a play I would
say that Wow it has incredible
production value really top-notch set
and costume design everyone and
everything looks really good but many of
the scenes and the personality traits of
the characters and the and the lines
that they're speaking seem painfully
familiar to productions I've already
seen from the zombies and The Flaming
Lips and and the Beatles and The Beach
Boys all of whom have put out records
that are a lot more ambitious larger in
scope more exciting and in some cases a
lot more raw meanwhile temple's comes
through with really huge booming drums
and some ultra fuzzy guitars hoping to
recreate the same kind of electricity
and I don't think it happens especially
since many of the
tracts on this LP seemed so uniform and
sound even if the band does offer a bit
of variety on the introduction to these
tracks or some of the guitar tones
across the LP I feel like temples have
sort of neglected to acknowledge a major
characteristic of some of the best
records in 60s psychedelic pop and rock
and that is their spontaneity the band
really leaves that characteristic out of
the picture and instead plays it pretty
straight and pretty bubblegum across the
12 tracks here still I think the band
sonic emulation of this style of music
is really good they have most of the
characteristics down that you would
expect from a record in this style and
each tune here has a pretty sharp yet
slightly derivative melody to it like
the tight syncopated guitar riffs and
drums on the title track here and there
really schmaltzy organ leads and chords
on the track the golden throne which
really is one of the better Tunes on
this entire LP they're really bright and
sunny guitar soloing at the start of the
song mesmerize is like pure ear candy
and I'm pretty impressed with the
instrumental the heavy instrumental
layering on the track move the season
there are a lot of very simple
straightforward feel-good psychedelic
pop tunes on this record that are very
pleasant to the ear but as I listen to
the album more and it draws on the more
impatient I get waiting for a single
novel idea to seep through the guitars
the bass lines the drums the vocals and
it just doesn't happen and the more I
listen to this LP the more apparent it
becomes that the group's approach to
song structure is pretty unexcited as
well I don't know if it's the lack of
surprises in these songs or if it's just
that the performances on this thing are
just so lacks they're just so smooth and
unexcited but there's just something
about many of these Tunes that by the
time I've hit the halfway point the song
has lost its flavor a little bit because
I kind of know what to expect
overall to me this record is just simply
put pop with a psychedelic veneer and
that's it it has great sound it has
great production it has a lot of
attention to detail in terms of the
aural experience of this record but I
feel like temples puts all of their eggs
in one basket on this thing and
totally neglects the idea of adventure
and expansion I think this record is
just a little too limited in scope and
ideas to be all that exciting or
interesting to me I'm feeling a strong 5
to a light 6 on this thing transition if
you've given this record to listen what
did you think of it did you love it hate
it why what do you think I should review
next and that's it
temples son structures forever
